title-group.article-title: A technique for motion capture of the finger using functional joint centres and the effect of calibration range of motion on its accuracy

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical and Systems Engineering, Newcastle University, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK

author-notes.corresp: Oliver ME Warlow, Bioengineering Group, School of Mechanical and Systems Engineering, Newcastle University, Stephenson Building, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, UK. Email: o.m.e.warlow@ncl.ac.uk

abstract.p: A method of kinematic analysis of the fingers using stereo-photogrammetry, referred to as the phalanx transformation technique, has been proposed. Functional methods were used to define the joint axes and subsequently each finger segments’ anatomical coordinate system. Thirteen subjects were tested and the accuracy of the technique assessed. The average error across the three joints of the finger was found to be 0.6 mm, which translates to a 2.2% error in predicted joint reaction force when using a biomechanical model. The subjects were required to have sufficient movement in their joints to define the joint axes functionally. Some subjects of clinical interest can have a significantly reduced mobility owing to injury or pathology, therefore, the effect of calibration range of motion on accuracy was analysed. It was found that, for a range of motion typical of a subject with rheumatoid arthritis, the errors in predicted joint reaction force were <7%. The accuracy of this technique compared favourably with others previously proposed and, considering the other errors inherent in modelling, those found in this study were deemed to be acceptable.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An improved understanding of finger biomechanics can aid in prevention, management and rehabilitation of injuries and pathologies of the fingers, optimise surgical interventions and improve design of joint replacements.1–3 The internal forces transmitted through the finger can be calculated using biomechanical models. Owing to the nature of activities carried out by the hand, a three-dimensional (3D) modelling approach is normally required, an accurate measurement of finger kinematics is a necessary input these models.

Owing to the small size of the phalanges of the finger, a marker-based stereo-photogrammetric technique is most commonly used for kinematic analysis. The requirement for 3D kinematic data for use with biomechanical models, makes use of one or two markers per segment, as proposed by previous authors, unsuitable.4–10 The ability to measure kinematics in 3D is compromised and there is often a necessity to place markers over anatomical locations, such as joint centres. Placing markers close to joint centres has been shown to have a detrimental effect on the skin movement artefact when applied to other limbs.11

Methods using one or two markers per phalanx allow only for an anatomical definition of the joint axes of rotation and not a functional definition. Anatomical definition means that the axes are defined relative to the position of externally located landmarks, whereas, using a functional definition, the axes are defined by the relative motion of adjacent body segments. Subjects, such as those with rheumatoid arthritis, may have such deformity at the joint that the position of joint axes anatomically scaled from healthy subjects would not be valid. Additionally, the location of functional axes is independent of any marker position, allowing the observer to attach markers in positions least likely to be affected by skin movement artefact. The location of the joint axes is crucial for prediction of the internal loading, previous work has shown that inaccuracies in the location of the axes can significantly alter these predictions.12

To enable the use of functional axes, groups of at least three non-collinear markers must be attached to each phalanx, these markers define cluster technical frames (CTFs). These CTFs can be rigidly attached to each phalanx and the dorsal surface of the hand using a tri-pod arrangement.13,14 Tripods however, can restrict the movement of the subject owing to the markers standing proud on the surface of the hand. To address this, CTFs have also been defined relative to markers attached directly to the skin.15,16 Only one study used a functional definition of the joint axes using a less intrusive marker set,15 in this case the joint axes were found using an algebraic fitting technique. The authors who used the tripod technique,14 used a transformation technique.17

All functional methods of joint definition require the subject to undertake a series of calibration movements to define the axes. For the most accurate definition, a large range of motion (RoM) for calibration is preferred in order to minimise errors from measurement noise and skin movement artefact. Subjects of biomechanical interest with pathology such as arthritis may have a significantly reduced RoM, fixed flexion–extension or ulna drift at the metacarpo-phalangeal (MCP) joint.18–23 None of the previous studies of the fingers examined the effect of a reduced RoM available for calibration. Because these subjects are of particular interest to the biomechanist, it is important to understand the influence of a reduced calibration RoM.

The first aim of this study was to propose a new marker set for kinematic analysis of the index finger using stereo-photogrammetry to achieve the greatest accuracy while minimising any impairment on the subjects’ movement. An ability to estimate the accuracy without any invasive imaging techniques would be of significant use to clinicians. The joint axes were defined functionally using a transformation technique, this leads to the second aim of assessing the suitability of this technique for subjects with a reduced calibration RoM. This was done both by analysing the effect of RoM on the position of the axes and also its effect on the predicted joint reaction force (JRF), which is a metric of interest to clinicians. The results will give future users of this technique an understanding of the mobility required of subjects to achieve accurate results.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The proposed marker set used markers attached in groups of three, in a non-collinear arrangement to define a CTF fixed to each phalanx and the dorsal surface of the hand (Figure 1). For the index finger, 12 hemispherical markers, 4 mm in diameter, were affixed using water soluble adhesive and the total mass of the 12 markers was 0.3 g. The conventions used to define the anatomical coordinate systems (ACSs) are described in the section ‘Definition of ACSs’.

caption.p: Position of markers P1–9 attached to the three phalanges of the right index finger and markers M1–3 attached to the dorsal surface of the hand. Positions S1–8 were pointed using a calibrated pointer. The proximally directed axis of the distal phalanx was defined by positions S1–6. The first approximation of the centre of the distal and proximal interphalangeal (DIP and PIP) joints were defined as the average of S5S6 and S7S8, respectively.

sec.p: The theory of the axis transformation technique (ATT)24 was used to define the axes of rotation (AoR) at the interphalangeal joints and the centre transformation technique (CTT)25 to define the centre of rotation (CoR) at the MCP joint. These techniques have only previously been applied to the large joints of the lower limb. This combination, in application to the small joints of the finger, is referred to as the phalanx transformation technique (PTT), a full description of which is given in the section ‘PTT’.

For calculation of the functional axes, subjects were required to perform a set of calibration movements. These were a full flexion–extension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, and full flexion–extension and abduction–adduction of the MCP joint. A reduced arc analysis was carried out to examine the effect of calibration RoM and is described in the section ‘Reduced arc analysis’.

Thirteen subjects (seven male and six female) were recruited to take part in the experiment (age: 24 (6) years; height: 1.77 (0.2) m; Mean (range)). A six camera Vicon T20 motion capture system (Vicon, UK) was used with a sampling rate of 100 Hz.

sec.title: Definition of ACSs
sec.p: Anatomical positions were defined in each phalanx CTF using a calibrated pointer, as is common in lower limb motion analysis.26 The pointer consisted of a rod 250 mm long, with markers positioned 25 mm and 50 mm from the pointed end. The positions S1–8 were pointed with the hand in a neutral pose (Figure 1). Positions S5–8 were positioned at the apex of the flexion crease on both the radial and ulna side of the interphalangeal joints. S5–8 were used to find the mid-point of the finger at either joint. S1 and S2 were positioned midway between the dorsal and palmar surface of the finger 5 mm proximal to the finger tip. Positions S3 and S4 bisected the lines created by S1S5 and S2S6. The positions S1–6 were then used to define the long axis of the distal phalanx.

The positions and orientations of each ACS are shown in Figure 2. Orientation was in accordance with the International Society of Biomechanics recommendations.27 The y-axis was directed proximally defining the long axis of the segment. The x-axis was directed palmarly and the y-axis defined the sagittal plane of the segment. The z-axis was perpendicular to this plane directed radially and was identical to the flexion AoR for the interphalangeal joints. The locations of the segment origins were chosen to match those proposed by Fowler et al.,28 with the origin being coincident with the joint centre at the proximal end of the segment. The origin of the metacarpal segment was chosen to be coincident with the origin of the proximal segment. The convention was chosen to suit the requirements of this study.

caption.p: Position and orientation of the anatomical coordinate systems (ACSs) of the phalanges and metacarpal of the right hand. For the each phalanx (d = distal, m = medial, p = proximal) the origin of each ACS was positioned at the joint centre at the proximal end of the segment. The metacarpal (mc) origin was defined as being coincident with the proximal phalanx origin. The x-axis was directed palmarly, the y-axis directed proximally and the z-axis directed radially for each segment.

sec.p: The pointed positions (S1–8) were combined with the functional axes to define the ACS for each segment. The AoR found from the calibration movements were of infinite length, therefore, it was necessary to find the point on this line closest to the centre of each phalanx to define its centre. The centres were defined by finding the point on the AoR closest to the mean of positions S5 and S6 for the DIP joint and positions S7 and S8 for the PIP joint. The MCP was defined as a CoR, therefore, no anatomical pointing was needed. The AoR themselves defined the z-axes of the distal, medial and proximal phalanges. As described previously, the y-axis of the distal phalanx was defined using positions S1–6. The y-axes of the medial and proximal phalanges were defined as the line linking the distal and proximal joint centres of that segment. A condition was placed on the y-axes, in that they had to be perpendicular to the existing z-axis. The dorsally directed x-axes were taken as the cross product of the z and y-axes for each segment.

sec.title: PTT
sec.p: The DIP and PIP joints were modelled as having one degree of freedom acting as a hinge about the flexion–extension axis. The MCP joint has two degrees of freedom, one about the flexion–extension axis and one about the abduction–adduction axis. For the purposes of defining a functional joint centre it was modelled as a spherical joint.

The ATT24 was used to find the AoR of the interphalangeal joints. This method assumed that there was a common AoR a between two adjacent segments (Figure 3). sec.title: Reduced arc analysis
sec.p: The methods of calculating the joint centres relied on the subject being able to carry out the calibration movements to as full an extent as possible. Potentially, subjects of future interest may have a significantly reduced RoM, therefore, the calibration data was adapted to simulate a reduced RoM. New sets of calibration data were created with arcs reduced from a magnitude equal to θf to a magnitude of zero in decrements of 2°. A new type of error was defined (eROM), equal to the vector between the original joint centre and those defined with the reduced arc (φ).
The total joint error (etotal) was expressed as the sum of this error and the original error
The worst case scenario was taken, i.e. the sign of ePTT was chosen to ensure the largest magnitude of etotal.

When reducing the RoM it was important to consider where φ was relative to the original θf. The subject could have a reduced RoM with the finger at an extended position, flexed position or somewhere between these two extremes. Simulations were made with three types of reduced arc; φI, φII and φIII. Type I with the minimum magnitude at full extension, Type II with the minimum at full flexion and Type III with the minimum in the middle of θf.

sec.title: Application to a biomechanical model
sec.p: A previous study on the sensitivity of a biomechanical model of the finger to changes in experimental input found the relationships between errors in the location of the joint centres and errors in model output12 as shown in Figure 4. The model used in this previous study was that proposed by Vigouroux et al.30 based on the normative model of An et al.1 Using these relationships the errors at each joint (eDIP, ePIP and eMCP) could be expressed as an error in predicted JRF (eJRF) for an open-handed grip type.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The components and magnitudes of the joint errors are shown in Figure 5. At the interphalangeal joints there was a distinct pattern with the error component ez being noticeably larger than both ex and ey. The magnitude (e) was, therefore, very similar to the magnitude of the component ez. At the MCP joint the pattern was less distinct although it still appeared that the error component ez was the largest. The magnitude of errors averaged across all three joints was 0.6 mm (Table 1). These errors were then expressed in terms of predicted JRF using a biomechanical model, giving a value of eJRF = 2.2%.

sec.p: The mean ||etotal|| of the Type I and II reductions were compared with numerical simulation studies (Figure 7).24,25 The numerical simulations follow an exponential profile at all joints. At the DIP joint the PTT had a smaller ||etotal|| than the numerical simulations. At the other two joints, ||etotal|| was similar between studies until the numerical simulation rose rapidly at a reduced arc of 35° for the PIP joint and 45° for the MCP joint.

Using the mean etotal of the Type I and II reductions eJRF was calculated. This error for a reduced RoM, typical of a subject with rheumatoid arthritis,21 is shown in Table 1 in addition to the magnitude ||etotal|| averaged across the three joints. The mean value of eJRF doubled in comparison to the unrestricted case to eJRF = 4.4%. The standard deviation also increased to 2.7%. Despite these increased it could be assumed that general errors in the predicted internal loading would be <7%.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study assessed the application of a skin-mounted marker set consisting of 12 × 4 mm hemispherical markers used to define the kinematics of the index finger using the PTT. This technique allowed an estimate of the error in the location of each joint centre to be made without invasive or imaging procedures. This meant the procedure could be carried out on multiple subjects within a standard motion analysis laboratory without the need for additional apparatus. Accurate definition of these joint centres is an important input to biomechanical models. For this reason the accuracy was also expressed in terms of predicted internal loading using a biomechanical model.

Previous authors have tried to assess the accuracy of their methods of motion capture. Repeatability of measured joint angles have been used,13 however, this does not provide a measure of accuracy adequate for most biomechanical modelling applications. A mechanical linkage of known dimensions has also been used.14 The use of such a linkage does not take into account skin movement artefact known to have an effect on accuracy.11,31–34 For assessment of the functional techniques used to define the ACS, numerical simulations have been carried out.15,24,25 These studies applied noise to simulate both skin movement artefact and experimental measurement uncertainty. However, with all simulations the way errors were introduced may not necessarily be an accurate representation of reality.

In this study the joint errors were assumed to be equal to half the magnitude of the discrepancy between segment origins calculated in adjacent CTFs. Discrepancy in the origin was computationally identical to the residuals fATT or fCTT depending on which joint was being considered. These residuals have been shown to correlate with joint error with a coefficient of 0.5,29 hence confirming the assumption. Ideally, a further study using cadavers or medical imaging would be needed. A goal of this study however, was to provide the observer with an estimate of the accuracy without the need for further measurement. Additionally, subjects of clinical interest may have radically altered anatomy making it difficult to define joint axes in a non-functional manner.

By looking at the components of the joint errors individually it was observed that the ez component was larger than the other two, particularly at the interphalangeal joints. This can be understood by considering how these joint centres were calculated. Because the AoR calculated initially were of infinite length, the average position of S5S6 and S7S8 were used to adjust the position of the joint centre to the middle of each phalanx. These AoR defined the z-axes of each ACS so the adjustments will affect the component of the error in this direction only.

The reliance on anatomical pointing to locate the AoR correctly means that this technique is not purely functional. To the authors’ knowledge, there is currently no way of fully defining the AoR without some form of input regarding anatomical positions. The MCP joint, however, was defined in a purely functional manner, therefore, the slight increase in ez compared with the other components was owing to other factors. The most likely cause of this is the limitation of assuming a spherical MCP joint for the kinematic model.

The influence of a calibrated RoM on accuracy in the determination of the ACSs was very important in determining this techniques’ applicability to those with an injury or pathology. From the reduced arc analysis, all reduction types resulted in similar ||etotal|| profiles, although with different magnitudes. Some of this difference in magnitude was owing to the skin movement artefact and could, therefore, be quantified by examination of the ||ePTT|| profiles.

At the interphalangeal joints the most skin movement artefact occurred when they were highly flexed, owing to the skin being stretched across the dorsal side of the joint. This agreed with the largest ||ePTT|| observed with Type II reduction (Figure 6), i.e. when the joint tended towards full flexion. From examination of ||ePTT|| for the Type I and Type III reductions, it can be concluded that there was little difference in skin movement artefact between them. When considering ||etotal|| however, the errors for Type III reduction were less than Type I. This was owing to there being a larger eROM when using the Type I reduction. eROM provided a measure of the displacement between the joint centre calculated using the full RoM and that calculated using the reduced arc. It can be assumed that displacement would be largest at the extremes of the RoM because that calculated from the full RoM would lie approximately in the middle of all calculated centres. This meant a larger value of eROM for the Type I reduction compared to Type III.

At the MCP joint the largest ||ePTT|| and ||etotal|| occurred when applying the Type I reduction. As this joint could extend more than the interphalangeal joints there was more skin movement artefact at full extension as the skin wrinkles on the dorsal surface. The smallest ||etotal|| was observed when applying the Type II reduction. Considering the results from the interphalangeal joints this was not as expected. As was noted previously in examination of the components of the errors, this indicates that the assumption of a spherical joint was not ideal in this case. It was, however, only when examining the errors in this level of detail that these limitations became apparent. Therefore, considering the overall accuracy achieved using this technique this spherical assumption was deemed acceptable.

Considering the interphalangeal joints, ||etotal|| at the DIP joint was less than the PIP joint. Markers P1 and P2 were attached directly to the finger nail and P3 was attached 2 mm proximal to it. These attachment locations are likely to result in minimal deformation of the CTF owing to skin movement artefact compared with the rest of the finger. This explains the decrease in error associated with the DIP joint compared with the PIP joint.

In comparison with previous numerical simulations24,25 the magnitude of the mean ||etotal|| for reduction at the DIP joint was smaller. As has been discussed, the deformation of the CTF at the DIP joint was minimal owing to the marker locations. Although the magnitude of ||etotal|| was similar at the PIP joint, the profiles differed, with the numerical simulation rising rapidly before the PTT. As noted previously, the error profile will change depending on what arc of motion is used. The numerical simulations used a Gaussian distribution for the error, rather than one that considered the range of flexion as having an effect on the skin artefact and could be a potential explanation for the difference in profile. At the MCP joint, a similar magnitude of ||etotal|| was observed, with a difference in profile for small calibration RoM for the same reasons.

To give an indication of this technique’s applicability to an arthritic patient, the typical ranges of motion for a subject with rheumatoid arthritis were applied21 to all the joints. Results indicate that the errors in predicted internal loading eJRF were typically <7%. This was compared with <3% error found when the subject had a full RoM. Considering other errors inherent in biomechanical modelling, however, this was deemed an acceptable margin of error.

The accuracy of the PTT compares favourably with previous functional methods of joint definition. For assessment of the hip joint Leardini et al.35 found that functional methods found the joint centre within around 13 mm of the geometric centre found using X-ray. Using the optimal common shape technique, Taylor et al.33 were able to find this joint centre to within 3.5 mm. The current study modelled the MCP as a spherical joint (like a hip) and the errors were 0.7 mm. For a hinge joint Schwartz and Rozumalski36 found the joint centre to within 3.8 mm. In the present study, the interphalangeal joints were defined as hinges with errors of 0.3–0.9 mm. It is important to note, however, that large skin artefacts are expected in the lower limb. Therefore, the decrease in errors in the current study was more owing to the difference in anatomy, rather than an improvement in motion capture techniques. Buczek et al.16 noted that there would be skin artefact, especially around the MCP joint, when the subject gripped a cylinder. As our study did not involve the subject interacting with any objects, this could not be quantified. However, it would be assumed that because the ACS are all defined in two adjacent segment CTFs the skin movement artefact would be reduced as much as possible.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In conclusion it has been shown that the proposed marker set, calibration movements and techniques used to calculate the segment ACSs, provides a useful tool for accurate calculation of finger kinematics in comparison with previously proposed techniques. For subjects with a reduced RoM it was shown that errors in predicted JRF could increase up to 7%. It is important to consider, however, that there is no typical subject, especially those with injury or pathology. Movement is still required for calibration using this technique. This work aimed only to quantify for what RoM accurate results could still be obtained rather than demonstrate its applicability to all subjects.
